concepts.text: A climate of brittle closeness where memory leans on the windshield as if under glass; proximity becomes gravity that refuses to settle, while breath fogs the pane and the engine hums as a distant tremor.
Snowbound static: interior silence thickens into a chamber; the car becomes a pressure vessel where remaining heat curls into cold air and every breath sounds like a question.
Red-trace echo: memory leaves a red glow on the snow and on the rear lights; desire is a fading track that refuses to disappear, a slow bleed of color in white space.
Threshold of equivalence: gravity equalizes, and two selves suspend in a neutral equilibrium; the world outside slides by, unremarkable, while inside a quiet gravity clamps the chest.
Icebound names: language crystallizes into ice; past identities sharpen into cold syllables on the windshield, turning the present into a skeptical grammar of what remains.

seeds.text: Brittle closeness; memory on glass; proximity as restless gravity; breath fogs the pane; distant tremor hums.
Snowbound silence; car as pressure vessel; heat curls into cold air; each breath a question.
Red-trace memory; glow on snow and rear lights; desire as fading track bleeding color through white space.
Equilibrium threshold; gravity equalizes; within, chest tightens; outside slides by unremarkable.
Icebound names; language crystallizes; past identities sharpen into cold syllables on the windshield.

poem.title: Registry Under Teeth
poem.text:
Clamp the jaw. Inside, a shelf of thin tags, each pressed with a sound that used to be warm.
The head keeps inventory even when the hands go still. The mouth is a locker. The lock resists.
Molars knock, a small percussion against bone, counting what should not be counted.

Choose a tag and the tongue loses heat, a swift white ache without light. The edges carry dates.
Hold it too long and the engraving prints into the soft part. The name arrives backwards, then splits.
What is held carries you until it starts to cut; what is released cuts faster. That is the bargain.

You wanted the old designation, the one that knew your weight. Say it, you said. Make it stand up.
When it slid forward it shaved the tip, a neat bright line, salt arriving before the sound.
Every letter turned into hardware. The palate went glassy and would not forgive.

The first attempt stalled at the ridge of the mouth, a cold plate welded where breath should go.
The second attempt scattered shavings. The third turned into swallowing and I did not mean to swallow.
Inside the throat, a door shut itself and stood there with its hand on your shoulder. Do not move.

Names are supposed to warm when spoken. These do not. They shrink from the lips and flare under the tongue.
The head tries to be a room, but the room is a drawer. The drawer slides, then sticks halfway.
You listen from the other side, palm on the cheek, heat making nothing happen.

Say it clean, you insist, as if there were a clean way. As if the metal would forgive the mouth for wanting.
The tag fogs the enamel—no, not fog, a dry burn, a held bright cold that argues with blood.
What it argues is that you can be kept if you mar me, and I keep reaching. I keep.

Now the mouth is open and it will not close. A plate rests against the roof and hums your smallest shape.
It will not drop into speech and it will not return to its slot. The jaw trembles trying to decide.
Touch it again and it will cut. Leave it alone and it will cut differently.

psychologist_notes.notes: Line-by-line pressure shows a sequence of rising pressure punctuated by blocks and ruptures, with intermittent diffusion and displacement. Early motion rises (line 1), then is blocked (line 2), followed by a continued rise (line 3). A diffusion at line 5 interrupts the ascent, then rupture appears (line 6) and an escalating loop forms (lines 6–7). A new rise reappears (line 9) and rupture follows (line 10) with a subsequent block (line 11). The pattern continues through blocked states (line 13) and another escalating loop (line 14) leading to a shutdown (line 15). A displacement occurs (line 17), followed by blocks (line 18) and diffusion (line 19). A renewed rise emerges (lines 21–23) and persists (line 25), then another block (line 26) precedes a final rupture (line 27).
leverage_for_poet: Line 2: rising pressure is interrupted by a block; escalation should resume rather than flatten.
Line 5: diffusion interrupts rising pressure; escalation should re-engage to preserve volatile tension.
Line 15: shutdown collapses movement; surface pressure should reappear rather than terminate.
leverage_for_architect: Line 1–2: rise→block transition; signal strain with a sharp boundary or abrupt spatial shift.
Line 6–7 and Line 14–15: escalating loops; require visible tightening/compression to show recursion.
Line 10 and Line 27: ruptures; ensure perceptible discontinuities in time or layout.
leverage_for_editor: Line 5 and Line 19 show diffusion; avoid smoothing tension; preserve residual volatility.
Blocked regions (Lines 2, 11, 13, 18, 22, 26) risk symmetrical stagnation; preserve nonuniformity to maintain instability.
Line 14–15 escalate toward shutdown; ensure volatility remains visible rather than tidied.

poem.title: Registry Under Teeth, Cut Either Way
poem.text:
Clamp the jaw. Inside, a shelf of thin tags, each pressed with a sound that used to be warm.
The head keeps inventory even when the hands go still. The mouth is a locker. The lock resists.
Molars knock,
        a small percussion against bone, counting what should not be counted, then counting again.

Choose a tag and the tongue loses heat, a swift white ache without light. The edges carry dates and a burr.
Hold it too long and the engraving prints into the soft part. The name arrives backwards, then splits.
What is held carries you until it starts to cut; what is released cuts faster. That is the bargain. It keeps getting made.

You wanted the old designation, the one that knew your weight.
    Say it, you said.
        Make it stand up.
When it slid forward it shaved the tip, a neat bright line, salt arriving before the sound.
Every letter turned into hardware. The palate went glassy and would not forgive.

The first attempt stalled at the ridge of the mouth, a cold plate welded where breath should go.
The second attempt scattered shavings. The third turned into swallowing and I did not mean to swallow.
Inside the throat, a door shut itself and stood there with its hand on your shoulder. Do not move.

Names are supposed to warm when spoken.
    These do not.
        They shrink from the lips and flare under the tongue.
The head tries to be a room, but the room is a drawer. The drawer slides, then jerks, then sticks halfway, the rails grind.
You listen from the other side, palm on the cheek, heat making nothing happen, the track shuddering.

Say it clean, you insist, as if there were a clean way. As if the metal would forgive the mouth for wanting.
The tag fogs the enamel—no, not fog, a dry burn, a held bright cold that argues with blood.
What it argues is that you can be kept if you mar me,
    and I keep reaching.
        I keep.

Now the mouth is open and it will not close.
A plate rests against the roof, wrong side down, and hums your smallest shape.
It will not drop into speech and it will not return to its slot. The jaw trembles trying to decide, decides, undecides.
Touch it again
    and it will cut.
        Leave it alone and it will cut differently.

summary: Poem A centers a concentrated sequence of tactile images around the jaw and mouth, maintaining a high intensity with a steady, building pressure. Poem B expands the sonic and mechanical register, introducing more line breaks and intermittent jerks that intensify disruption and motif variety. Both poems sustain Siken-like urgency and a singular interior tension, but they deploy structure and imagery differently to sustain momentum.
risks_or_regressions: Poem A risks narrower texture that may feel more compressed, potentially reducing sonic variety; Poem B risks heavy fragmentation that can hinder clarity and reader alignment with the speaker’s voice.

bullets: Region: the close-open loop near 'Now the mouth is open' through 'it will not return to its slot' (approx lines 33–37). Issue: a sustained deadlock that stalls momentum and flattens pressure, as closure remains impossible and motion stalls. Direction: sustain instability by deepening the undecidability and pushing the loop toward a more volatile inversion rather than a stalemate.

Region: the sequence of attempts (the first stall, the second scattering, the third swallowing) around lines 15–18. Issue: rupture creates blocked breath, producing a moment of blocked propulsion; the pressure collapses into a fixed obstruction. Direction: heighten contradiction by intensifying the sense of obstruction or by redefining what 'breath' or 'breathability' means in the system.

Region: the dual imperative at the end (lines 39–41). Issue: two paths with indistinguishable outcomes flatten into a tidy binary; there is no emergent pressure from choosing one. Direction: escalate recurrence by amplifying the consequences of both paths, keeping the tension in unresolved potential rather than resolving.

Region: the drawer/room metaphor at lines around 24–25. Issue: the imagery slips into a neat metaphor that reduces the fracturing of perception; the internal logic risks becoming too tidy and explanatory. Direction: sustain instability by sharpening the misfit between spaces and their functions, keeping cognitive dissonance active.

Line 16: The line containing the first mouth-stress is split into two lines; the second fragment indented 12 spaces ('a cold plate welded where breath should go.') to show a deep inversion (rising -> blocked).
Line 18: The sentence with Inside the throat is split so that the imperative 'Do not move.' becomes its own line indented by 8 spaces after the preceding clause.
Line 32: The line containing 'Now the mouth is open' is split into two lines, with the second line indented by 8 spaces ('        and it will not close.').

Line 34: The sentence starting with 'It will not drop into speech and it will not return to its slot' is broken into three lines with 0, 4, and 8 spaces to create an escalating loop: 'It will not drop into speech' / '    and it will not return to its slot.' / '        The jaw trembles trying to decide, decides, undecides.'

        Leave it alone and it will cut differently.

poem.title: Registry Under Teeth, Wrong Side Down
poem.text:
Clamp the jaw. Inside, a shelf of thin tags, each pressed with a sound that used to be warm.
The head keeps inventory even when the hands go still. The mouth is a locker. The lock resists.
Molars knock,
        a small percussion against bone, counting what should not be counted, then counting again.

Choose a tag and the tongue loses heat, a swift white ache without light. The edges carry dates and a burr.
Hold it too long and the engraving prints into the soft part. The name arrives backwards, then splits.
What is held carries you until it starts to cut; what is released cuts faster. That is the bargain. It keeps getting made.

You wanted the old designation, the one that knew your weight.
    Say it, you said.
        Make it stand up.
When it slid forward it shaved the tip, a neat bright line, salt arriving before the sound.
Every letter turned into hardware. The palate went glassy and would not forgive.

The first attempt stalled at the ridge of the mouth,
            a cold plate welded where breath should go.
Breath stopped being breath, went solid, a lid inside the lid.
The second attempt scattered shavings. The third turned into swallowing and I did not mean to swallow. It was not hunger; it was storage.
Inside the throat, a door shut itself and stood there with its hand on your shoulder. The shoulder was inside too.
        Do not move.

Names are supposed to warm when spoken.
    These do not.
        They shrink from the lips and flare under the tongue.
The head tries to be a room, but the room is a drawer from the wrong locker. The drawer slides, then jerks, then sticks halfway, the rails grind bone and metal together.
You listen from the other side, palm on the cheek, heat making nothing happen, the track shuddering without finding a track.

Say it clean, you insist, as if there were a clean way. As if the metal would forgive the mouth for wanting.
The tag fogs the enamel—no, not fog, a dry burn, a held bright cold that argues with blood.
What it argues is that you can be kept if you mar me,
    and I keep reaching.
        I keep.

Now the mouth is open
        and it will not close.
A plate rests against the roof, wrong side down, and hums your smallest shape, the hum going through bone and back.
It will not drop into speech
    and it will not return to its slot.
        The jaw trembles trying to decide, decides, undecides.
Closing bites it deeper.
    Opening exposes more edge.
Touch it again
    and it will cut.
        Leave it alone and it will cut differently.
It will count you if you touch it, tally by tally along the wound it recognizes.
    It will count the space if you do not, a running sum where your weight used to fit.

summary: Poem A presents a compact, visceral chain of bodily images that centers on control and cutting; Poem B expands the same mechanism, adding storage and tally motifs that intensify urgency. Both poems carry a Siken-like intensity, but Poem B escalates more overtly and introduces new mechanical motifs that raise the pace and density of images. The shift in line breaks and added imagery in Poem B broadens the motif field while preserving the core tension around speech, weight, and possession. Overall, the two texts share a center of gravity but differ in momentum and scope of imagery.
risks_or_regressions: Poem B's increased brutality and density could overwhelm the underlying emotional thread or clarity of the speaker's arc. Both poems remain heavily image-driven, which may limit accessibility for some readers.

psychologist_notes.notes: Line-by-line the pressure field initiates with rising pressure as constriction is applied (Line 1). A block emerges when the mechanism resists closure (Line 2), followed by further rising pressure (Line 3) and a looping surface as counting repeats (Line 4). A new rise occurs (Line 6) and a rupture-like transition appears (Line 7) that escalates into an escalating loop (Line 8). After a brief mid-section, the pattern returns to rising pressure (Line 10–12) and pushes toward a rupture (Line 13), which is followed by a blocking rigidity (Line 14) and a shutdown state (Line 18). A displacement phase moves energy outward (Line 19) and a secondary rupture occurs (Line 20), with renewed rising tension (Line 21). The sequence cycles through a series of blocks, loops, and escalations (Lines 23–33), before a diffuse release state emerges (Line 35–36) and a sustained shutdown region forms (Line 37–39). A looping oscillation reappears (Line 40) that intensifies into an escalating loop (Line 41) and shifts toward a rupture-oriented progression (Line 42). Subsequent lines return to rising pressure (Line 43–44), with a branching potential for different outcomes that remains within a diffusive-to-blocking regime (Line 45–47). Overall, the poem maintains a pattern of recurring rise, blockage, rupture, and escalating loops, rarely culminating in a stable reset, thereby sustaining high internal pressure with intermittent resets but no definitive resolution.
leverage_for_poet: Line 2 demonstrates rising pressure interrupted by a block; the regulating mechanism blocks escalation too early. Mechanically, the stake is to permit escalation to continue past the block rather than settling into stability.
Line 4 presents a looping surface that returns without heightened instability; the leverage is to sharpen the loop so that repetition increases ultimate instability rather than neutralizing it.
Line 18 shows a shutdown that drains volatility; the leverage is to preserve volatility by preventing collapse and maintaining a state that could feed renewed pressure.
leverage_for_architect: Highlight rise→block transitions (e.g., Lines 1–2) so the layout spatially signals crossing of a pressure barrier.
Mark rupture→escalation transitions (Lines 7–8) with visible compression or structural tightening to reflect rising risk in the space.
Annotate shutdown events (Lines 18–19, 37–39) to trigger a perceptible reset in spatial grounding and prevent a tidy closure.
leverage_for_editor: Flag regions where pressure stagnates or becomes too symmetrical (e.g., Lines 3–4) to preserve Siken-like instability rather than smoothing into neutrality.
Identify diffusions or shutdowns that overly soften tension (Lines 14–18, 37–39) and ensure they remain volatile rather than resolved.
Point out looping returns without increased pressure or altered valence (Lines 27, 40–41) and preserve their conflictual potential rather than neutralizing repetition.

(12 spaces) to visually mark the inversion pivot.

(12 spaces).

Reflow the 'Molars knock' line into a three-part cascade to escalate tension: 'Molars knock,' (0 spaces); '    a small percussion against bone,' (4 spaces); '        counting what should not be counted, then counting again.' (8 spaces).

Introduce additional deliberate blank lines at key pressure points to create negative-space voltage (pauses that emphasize cycles of rise and rupture), e.g., after the initial cascades and before the next major sections.

bullets: Region around the inversion pivot: The head tries to be a room, but the room is a drawer from the wrong locker, followed by The drawer slides, then jerks, then sticks halfway, the rails grind bone and metal together. Issue: the inversion yields a vivid image but the momentum after the pivot risks flattening; tension does not continue to spiral. Adjustment: sustain instability by pushing the pivot’s consequences into a longer cascade that intensifies the mechanical contradiction.

Blockage and containment around the first rupture sequence (The first attempt stalled ... Do not move). Issue: a brief containment moment reduces volatility and risks a tidy reset rather than ongoing rupture. Adjustment: extend the rupture-drive so that subsequent blocks fail to simply freeze, preserving volatile energy and delaying resolution.

Final counting/recurrence near the open mouth: It will count you if you touch it, tally by tally along the wound it recognizes. It will count the space if you do not, a running sum where your weight used to fit. Issue: recurrence returns without introducing new destabilizing stakes; the counting loop risks becoming a self-contained, explanatory mechanism. Adjustment: escalate recursion by coercing the counting to yield a fresh pressure shift or a rupture cue, maintaining the conflict rather than letting repetition neutralize it.

Split the line containing inversion in 'The head tries to be a room, but the room is a drawer from the wrong locker' into two lines: 'The head tries to be a room,' (0 spaces) and '            but the room is a drawer from the wrong locker.' (12 spaces) to visually mark the inversion pivot.

(12 spaces).

Reflow the 'Molars knock' line into a three-part cascade to escalate tension: 'Molars knock,' (0 spaces); '    a small percussion against bone,' (4 spaces); '        counting what should not be counted, then counting again.' (8 spaces).

Reflow the block around 'The first attempt stalled at the ridge of the mouth,' into a four-part cascade: 'The first attempt stalled at the ridge of the mouth,' (0 spaces); '    a cold plate welded where breath should go.' (4 spaces); '        Breath stopped being breath,' (8 spaces); '            went solid, a lid inside the lid.' (12 spaces).

Extend the subsequent fragmenting of the second and third attempts with cascading indentation: 'The second attempt scattered shavings.' (0 spaces); '        The third turned into swallowing and I did not mean to swallow.' (8 spaces); '            It was not hunger; it was storage.' (12 spaces).

Introduce additional deliberate blank lines at key pressure points to create negative-space voltage (pauses that emphasize cycles of rise and rupture), e.g., after the initial cascades and before the next major sections.

    and I keep reaching.

poem.title: Registry Under Teeth, Wrong Side Down
poem.text:
Clamp the jaw. Inside, a shelf of thin tags, each pressed with a sound that used to be warm.
The head keeps inventory even when the hands go still. The mouth is a locker. The lock resists.
Molars knock,
    a small percussion against bone,
        counting what should not be counted, then counting again.

Choose a tag and the tongue loses heat, a swift white ache without light. The edges carry dates and a burr.
Hold it too long and the engraving prints into the soft part. The name arrives backwards, then splits.
What is held carries you until it starts to cut; what is released cuts faster. That is the bargain. It keeps getting made.

"You wanted the old designation, the one that knew your weight."
    Say it, you said.
        Make it stand up.
When it slid forward it shaved the tip, a neat bright line, salt arriving before the sound.
Every letter turned into hardware. The palate went glassy and would not forgive.

The first attempt stalled at the ridge of the mouth,
    a cold plate welded where breath should go.
        Breath stopped being breath,
            went solid, a lid inside the lid.
The second attempt scattered shavings.
        The third turned into swallowing and I did not mean to swallow.
            It was not hunger; it was storage.
Inside the throat, a door shut itself and stood there with its hand on your shoulder. The shoulder was inside too.
        Do not move.
            But the hinge ticked inside the jaw.
                The lid shook under the lid.
                    Heat stayed, a dry burn waiting in the dark of the mouth.
                        The order held and did not hold.

Names are supposed to warm when spoken.
    These do not.
        They shrink from the lips and flare under the tongue.
The head tries to be a room,
            but the room is a drawer from the wrong locker.
The drawer slides,
    then jerks,
        then sticks halfway,
            the rails grind bone and metal together.
                then backs out a little,
                    then lunges crooked,
                        the slot refuses the body,
                            the body refuses the slot.

You listen from the other side, palm on the cheek, heat making nothing happen, the track shuddering without finding a track.

Say it clean, you insist, as if there were a clean way. As if the metal would forgive the mouth for wanting.
The tag fogs the enamel—no, not fog, a dry burn, a held bright cold that argues with blood.
What it argues is that you can be kept if you mar me,
    and I keep reaching.
        I keep.

Now the mouth is open
        and it will not close.
A plate rests against the roof, wrong side down, and hums your smallest shape, the hum going through bone and back.
It will not drop into speech
    and it will not return to its slot.
        The jaw trembles trying to decide, decides, undecides.
Closing bites it deeper.
    Opening exposes more edge.
Touch it again
    and it will cut.
        Leave it alone and it will cut differently.
It will count you if you touch it, tally by tally along the wound it recognizes.
    It will count the space if you do not, a running sum where your weight used to fit.
        It will start marking the enamel with tallies you cannot say,
            pressing each mark through to bone.
                It will miscount on purpose.
                    You will correct it with blood.
                        The count rises whether or not you answer.

summary: Poem_a and poem_b both embody Siken-like urgency through bodily imagery of the jaw, teeth, and enclosure; poem_b intensifies escalation and expands the motif network with additional lines about hinges, tallies, and enamel. The core tension remains tied to grasping and releasing identity, but poem_b amplifies the sense of reckoning and inevitability while poem_a maintains a leaner, more restrained arc. The differences in line breaks and added sequences in poem_b contribute to a more enveloping rhythm and sharper propulsion toward a climactic sense of consequence.
risks_or_regressions: Poem_b's expanded sequence may risk diluting the immediate pressure of the central image and feeling overworked for some readers. Poem_a preserves a tighter, more claustrophobic tempo, which carries strong Siken-like tension but offers less explosive escalation than poem_b. Overall both maintain consistent persona alignment, with poem_b pushing the envelope more aggressively.

summary: Both poems stage a claustrophobic anatomy of speech and possession through visceral dental imagery and repetitive bargaining. Poem B amplifies escalation by adding line-break fragmentation, new mechanical adjectives, and denser motifs, increasing the sense of constraint and risk. Motifs of tags, engraving, and hardware recur in both, but B deepens their recurrence with nested actions and louder physicality. Neither poem is straightforwardly a revision of the other; they present two fixed artefacts with parallel tensions, each achieving a distinct intensity within the same persona framework.
risks_or_regressions: B's higher density and nested line-work may obscure emotional throughline for readers not attuned to its cadence. A, while urgent, may risk under-deploying escalation compared with B, potentially reducing its intensity within the same persona framework. Overall, both poems hold strong alignment to the persona's pressure-logic, but each version emphasizes a different balance between clarity and visceral intensity.
